subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Alphabet project day 2
msgSnippet: Paul: If you look at the manual, p2, there are differences between the three letters you ask about.  Look at the beginning and ending points and whether a
messageBody:
Paul:

If you look at the manual, p2, there are differences between the three letters you ask about.  Look at the beginning and ending points and whether a vertical line drawn through the beginning would touch the end of the letter or not.  The top of Shush is just about directly over the bottom of the letter, and it slopes more to the right (i.e. there is more of an arch) than Th-ey does.  Thither begins to the left of where it ends, probably to insure that it is not mistaken for P-ea..  Th-ey ends directly under where it starts.  So, the short answer is, no.  They aren't mirror images of each other.

Bob and Pipe are mirror images except that Bob bends back as it approaches the base line in order to make it possible to connect to the next letter if it starts at the base line.  This is a change from Shavian in which the two letters were mirror images, if my memory is correct.

Paige

Paul Tremblay wrote:

This day is brought to you by the letter Fife. And Thither. And about 10
others.

I have finished most of the cosonants. I just tried to send them as
a zipped file but the file was too big.

I have started a project at sourceforge where I can load the files, so
I'll have to find a convenient way to to put the files there.

A few questions: Are Thither and Thoth exact mirror images, and is Shush
(She) just a higher Thither? And are Bob and Pipe mirror images? I
have made all of these letters nearly identical.

Thanks

Paul
